abstract: China is failing to carry out its pledges to liberalize its economy and open its markets to foreign companies, according to the European Union.
snippet: China is failing to carry out its pledges to liberalize its economy and open its markets to foreign companies, according to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: China is failing to carry out its pledges to liberalize its economy and open its markets to foreign companies, according to the European Union, which accused the nation of protectionism to prop up its domestic industry. “Even though China reiterates its firm commitment to continued opening-up and reform, this does not duly characterize the current situation in China,” John Clarke, head of the European Union’s delegation to the World Trade Organization, said on Monday during China’s trade policy review in Geneva. “In fact, our companies have reported a worsening of the business climate.” Mr. Clarke said China used a weak currency, export incentives and subsidies to bolster its economy. Trade in goods between the bloc and China was worth 296 billion euros ($364 billion) last year.

headline.main: In Review, Europe Accuses China of Protectionism

The power of moving images to drive public opinion in the midst of an unfolding crisis became apparent with the video of a young woman, Neda, dying of a head wound during protests in Iran. So it’s little wonder that in the confrontation this week between Turkey’s Freedom Flotilla and the Israeli Navy, both sides came armed with cameras. The truth, though, remains elusive. abstract: Fundamentally, the failures of BP’s management to prepare for, and then handle, the crisis, evoke striking parallels with those of the now-bankrupt Lehman.

lead_paragraph: BP is shaping up to be the oil industry’s Lehman Brothers. Moreover, as in the financial industry, the policy response will almost certainly lead to seismic changes in the energy business.

lead_paragraph: Walk around immigrant neighborhoods anywhere in the United States and you will see signs in storefronts each offering the cheapest rate to send money back home. In Mexico and other Latin American countries, these flows from workers, known as remittances, help support families, back new businesses and even plug holes in the balance of payments account.

headline.main: Sending More Money South of the Border

abstract: I’m the first guy to lead the charge against cell-carrier greed. But AT&T’s plan to end its unlimited data plan for smartphones is different. This time, I think you’ll wind up coming out ahead.

lead_paragraph: Robin Domeniconi has been named the new chief brand officer for Elle magazine, overseeing its content, advertising and marketing. Ms. Domeniconi most recently worked as a vice president at Microsoft, where she was in charge of sales and marketing for media properties. But she has a history in the magazine world, too, having run sales and marketing at Time Inc. and working as publisher and president of Real Simple. Carol Smith left the position at Elle in April to work at Condé Nast, overseeing the company’s new epicurean group. Ms. Domeniconi starts full time in July, according to Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S., Elle’s publisher.

abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes.
snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission delayed trading curbs for Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index listings when they rise or fall 10 percent in five minutes, saying they will be implemented within two weeks. The announcement was made in an e-mail statement. NYSE Euronext said earlier Friday that it would not start its trial of the system on June 7 because it had not received S.E.C. authorization. The Nasdaq OMX Group is prepared to introduce circuit breakers on the S.& P. 500 companies it lists on June 14, pending S.E.C. approval, a spokesman, Robert Madden, said.

headline.main: S.E.C. Delays Start of Exchange Trading Curbs

abstract: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation’s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world’s largest initial public offering on record.
snippet: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation’s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world’s largest initial public offering on record.
lead_paragraph: The Agricultural Bank of China, one of the nation’s biggest lenders, will sell a 15 percent stake in what may be the world’s largest initial public offering on record. The state-owned bank plans to sell 22.235 billion shares in Shanghai and 25.411 billion shares in Hong Kong, excluding an over-allotment option, according to a prospectus posted on the securities regulator’s Web site Friday. Agricultural Bank will compete for investors’ money with publicly traded rivals that plan to raise a combined $32 billion in stock and bond sales even with bank valuations near record low levels. Agricultural Bank will have 26.73 billion shares outstanding in Hong Kong after the offering, which includes 25.411 billion shares sold to the public and another 1.32 billion shares held by China’s national pension fund. The prospectus did not give a price range for the share sale or an amount that the lender would seek to raise. China’s securities regulator said it would review the plan on June 9.

headline.main: Agricultural Bank of China to Sell Shares
headline.print_headline: Agricultural Bank of China To Sell Shares

abstract: Legislators already opposed to small-business credit card reform will no doubt wave the report when they make their floor speeches. But does it really offer guidance?
snippet: Legislators already opposed to small-business credit card reform will no doubt wave the report when they make their floor speeches. But does it really offer guidance?
lead_paragraph: Last year, when Congress passed the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure Act, it declined to extend new consumer protections against certain card company practices to small business accounts. This was in part because some legislators expressed concern that nobody had properly studied how such a move might affect the price and availability of credit for small companies. So Congress directed the Federal Reserve to look into the matter. The nation’s monetary policy makers recently delivered their conclusion. It was not terribly conclusive.

headline.main: The Fed Weighs In on Credit Card Reform

abstract: The Next Newsweek: Solving the math on a weekly publishing problem.
snippet: The Next Newsweek: Solving the math on a weekly publishing problem.
lead_paragraph: In today’s Media Equation column, I made my own attempt to address the very tough math of re-making a version of Newsweek that would survive and thrive in a busy, wired news ecosystem. With the magazine up for sale, others have weighed in: Jeff Bercovici of Daily Finance suggests that Newsweek begin by paying attention to the magazine and little else,  and Lee Siegel argues in the New York Observer that its current leadership is to blame. But rather than do forensics on what went wrong — at bottom, the world changed — we asked a folks by e-mail and on Twitter for new answers.

headline.main: Newsweek: Crowd-Sourcing the Next Version

abstract: More playful puzzles of Martin Gardner.
snippet: More playful puzzles of Martin Gardner.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we bid a fond farewell to Martin Gardner, who died on May 22. However, fond farewells have a habit of lingering on, and we will not take leave of the spirit of Mr. Gardner just yet. As a not-unknown poet once said, “Parting is such sweet sorrow, that I shall say good night till it be morrow.” In our case, circumstances have conspired to prolong our farewell at least one week. And it is only fitting. After all, if puzzling were geometry, we have just lost our Euclid.

headline.main: Numberplay: The Playful Mr. Gardner

Casey’s does not have a staggered board, so all of its directors are up for election this year. Well spoken and polite, he seemed to be wearing an invisible helmet and pads from his high school football days. So guarded was Mr. Isidori that he kept his passions under his toque, and his personality under wraps. The less he revealed, the more I felt myself clamming up.

headline.main: Why I Hired Chef Joe

abstract: One provision could have a big impact on owners of Subchapter S corporations.
snippet: One provision could have a big impact on owners of Subchapter S corporations.
lead_paragraph: The Senate this week takes up a tax extenders bill with provisions that are sure to please small businesses. The American Jobs and Closing Tax Loopholes Act of 2010 — which has already passed the House twice and the Senate once — resuscitates many business tax benefits that expired at the end of last year. It also revives provisions in the stimulus bill that have bolstered Small Business Administration lending by increasing loan guarantees and eliminating borrower fees. Several times those measures have expired before winning short-term extensions from Congress, but they have not yet been renewed after running out of money and legal authority at the end of May. This bill will extend them through the end of the year.

headline.main: Tax Bill Would Benefit Small Businesses — and Burden Some, Too

lead_paragraph: A $238 million basketball arena is rising on Main Street, financed through a bond deal underwritten by Goldman Sachs. At the corner of Main and Fourth sits a branch of UBS Financial Services, the brokerage arm of the giant Swiss bank. Once known as Whiskey Row, Main Street and the surrounding blocks are now lined with bank towers: BB&T, PNC, National City and Your Community Bank.

headline.main: In Louisville, a View of Big Banks’ Everyday Role

abstract: Carla Thompson got tired of reading articles that asked where the female entrepreneurs were.
snippet: Carla Thompson got tired of reading articles that asked where the female entrepreneurs were.
lead_paragraph: Recently, someone asked me why women don’t support each other in business. The question threw me because it presumed a fact that seemed dubious at best — and completely contrary to the reality I’ve experienced, both personally and through the stories I’ve written about women who own businesses. The “cat fight” narrative might draw viewers to reality TV shows and romantic comedies, but it’s not helpful to the female business owner eager to learn from and share with her peers.

headline.main: Women Don’t Help Each Other?

abstract: The prize money is nice, but there are other rewards.
snippet: The prize money is nice, but there are other rewards.
lead_paragraph: In business competitions, as in business, the odds of winning are stacked against entrepreneurs. Of course, the chance to meet investors and partners and to get expert feedback — along with the possibility of scoring prize money — are chief among the reasons students tend to compete. But why would companies that are already up and running, and in some cases venture backed, risk it? And when they lose, is it worth it?

headline.main: The Value of Losing a Business Competition

abstract: The Deal Professor argues that the mind-set of many top regulators, as capable as they may be, is too often skewed in favor of Wall Street and against tougher regulatory measures.
snippet: The Deal Professor argues that the mind-set of many top regulators, as capable as they may be, is too often skewed in favor of Wall Street and against tougher regulatory measures.
lead_paragraph: The fate and scope of financial reform is now left to the Senate and House conference committee, which is putting together the final bill. It is an unsettling time as the struggle over derivatives reform, the Volcker Rule and untold nuances and seemingly minor provisions are left to jockeying among elected representatives. Yet, while there are many good things in the bill that should form the core of any financial reform and subsequent acts by Congress, there is one area — perhaps the key one — that this bill fails to address.

headline.main: The Government’s Elite and Regulatory Capture

abstract: Groupe Danone, the yogurt maker, agreed to buy Medical Nutrition USA for about $62.3 million, adding protein supplements for the elderly to its medical-nutrition business in the United States.
snippet: Groupe Danone, the yogurt maker, agreed to buy Medical Nutrition USA for about $62.3 million, adding protein supplements for the elderly to its medical-nutrition business in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Groupe Danone, the yogurt maker, agreed to buy Medical Nutrition USA for about $62.3 million, adding protein supplements for the elderly to its medical-nutrition business in the United States. Danone will pay $4 a share, 44 percent more than the closing price Thursday for Medical Nutrition, which makes Pro-Stat proteins, Danone said. The purchase would bolster Danone’s medical nutrition unit, which increased sales 8.3 percent last year to 925 million euros ($1.1 billion), accounting for 6 percent of total revenue. Medical Nutrition USA makes liquid proteins that are predigested by fruit enzymes, helping people with protein deficiencies and accelerating tissue healing in patients with ulcers, according to its Web site.

headline.main: Groupe Danone Agrees to Buy Medical Nutrition

abstract: What explains the rise of good-hitting middle infielders?

That is, all four groups have converged toward the average in recent decades. Baseball fans will have no trouble coming up with examples: good-hitting infielders like Chase Utley, Derek Jeter, Dustin Pedroia, Hanley Ramirez — or the general lack of good D.H.’s this season.

lead_paragraph: O.K., here’s my deal with Twitter. Personally, I have a hard time doing anything in 140 characters or less. Maybe it’s a difference of the sexes thing. Research tells us more men than women are on Twitter while the Facebook community (which offers free-flowing prose if you choose) is heavier in estrogen. No surprise there really. Men tend to be bottom-liners and women seem to enjoy talking about their experiences more.

abstract: It makes sense that the BP disaster would weigh more heavily than the Greek debt crisis on stocks: it lays bare the limits of human capability.
snippet: It makes sense that the BP disaster would weigh more heavily than the Greek debt crisis on stocks: it lays bare the limits of human capability.
lead_paragraph: Forget Greece. The biggest blow to global investor confidence right now lies 5,000 feet below the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. That may sound odd. At worst, the disaster at the Macondo well would wipe out one big company, BP; a sovereign default, on the other hand, could domino throughout stock, bond and currency markets, bringing down some of the Continent’s biggest banks and potentially breaking up the single currency.

abstract: Rising ad tide seems to be leaving one boat, made out of newsprint, stuck to the bottom
snippet: Rising ad tide seems to be leaving one boat, made out of newsprint, stuck to the bottom
lead_paragraph: They say that bad news comes in threes, but it’s really just a convenient trope that journalists use as a crutch to avoid writing an actual lead. Then again, it’s a nice way to cluster all the bad news about one’s profession so as not to dwell on it. Suffice to say that the in-box contained some signs this week that the long-running question of whether newspapers were suffering mostly from a cyclical (ads are down) or secular (ads have gone elsewhere) decline seems to have been settled. The answer is both.

headline.main: Bounce in Ads Returns, but Skips Newspapers

lead_paragraph: Our sister blog The Choice is reporting that Cablevision has announced that it is offering a free SAT preparation course as an incentive for people to subscribe to its Optimum service. Cablevision has systems throughout the New York area, an epicenter of the highly selective college admissions chase. By dangling the prospect of higher test scores as a carrot for subscribers, the company has elevated SAT tutoring to a status previously occupied by such come-ons as the PBS tote bag, the Sports Illustrated fleece jacket and the Time magazine alarm clock.

lead_paragraph: As longtime readers know, I think the cellphone industry is one step away from a big-city mugger. Some of their practices are outrageous ripoffs-like how they charge so much for text messages (both the sender and the receiver), even though text messages cost them nothing. Or how the purpose of two-year contract is to sell you an expensive phone cheaply, on the premise that you'll pay it off over the next 24 months -- but once you've paid off the phone, your monthly bill doesn't go down. (Except at T-Mobile.)

headline.main: Is Verizon Wireless Making It Harder to Avoid Charges?

abstract: The Southern Company, the giant utility owner, agreed to a $3.4 billion federal loan guarantee to build the country’s first nuclear power plant in three decades.
snippet: The Southern Company, the giant utility owner, agreed to a $3.4 billion federal loan guarantee to build the country’s first nuclear power plant in three decades.
lead_paragraph: The Southern Company, the giant utility owner, agreed to a $3.4 billion federal loan guarantee to build the country’s first nuclear power plant in three decades. The guarantee covers up to 70 percent of Southern’s eligible projected costs, the company said Friday. “This is another step forward on the road to nuclear power playing a prominent role in America’s energy future,” David Ratcliffe, the chief executive, said in a statement. Southern would be the first to receive federal aid under a five-year-old law aimed in part at helping add nuclear stations, which usually cost more and take longer to build than coal or natural-gas-fired generators. Southern plans to add two reactors to its Vogtle station near Waynesboro, Ga., in 2016 and 2017.

headline.main: $3.4. Billion Guarantee for New Nuclear Plant

lead_paragraph: Caterpillar, the world’s largest maker of construction equipment, said worldwide retail sales of machinery measured over three months rose for the first time in almost two years. Then we broadened our focus, throwing away items that had passed their expiration date or were no longer needed. Then we made a list of things to buy and went shopping.

lead_paragraph: The meaning of Father’s Day has changed for me over the years. My father has been gone a couple of years now, and my kids are almost out of the house. I’ve been a father for 28 years, an entrepreneur for 32. As with any demanding job, balancing the responsibilities of parenthood with the responsibilities of the business has been a challenge. abstract: A set of puzzles that allow the reader to prove Bell’s theorem, which has been called “the most profound discovery of Science.”
snippet: A set of puzzles that allow the reader to prove Bell’s theorem, which has been called “the most profound discovery of Science.”
lead_paragraph: After my whimsical travels of the last week, it is good to come back to Numberplay (incidentally, we finally have this convenient URL that you can bookmark to get access to all Numberplay posts). In today’s post, I will leave all whimsy aside, and show you that the universe we inhabit is stranger that our fictitious imaginings. Today we will explore a fundamental and almost unbelievable result of Quantum Mechanics (QM) through a set of simple puzzles. This famous result is “Bell’s Interconnectedness Theorem” which was discovered by the physicist John Stewart Bell in 1964. Bell’s theorem has been called by physicist Henry Stapp “the most profound discovery of Science.” It is profound because it shows that the universe has the property of non-locality: two particles can be light years apart, yet they are linked to each other instantaneously. How instantaneously? Recent measurements have shown that this phenomenon occurs more than 10,000 times the speed of light! In order to show that the universe in non-local, Bell showed that a certain simple and obvious inequality – Bell’s inequality – is violated. Amazingly, the only math that you need to understand this profound inequality is contained in the following simple problem.

headline.main: Numberplay: Spooky Action at a Distance

abstract: The only reason we invest in stocks is to earn more than we would get from cash or bonds. The amount you are supposed to earn by taking the additional risk of owning stocks is called the risk premium. So when is it coming back?

lead_paragraph: Austerity — it’s moving to Europe, so you might as well get used to it. But aside from cuts and more cuts, what does it mean exactly? With an odd poetic justice, it’s a word with Greek roots, meaning harsh and bitter, not far from the taste people will have in their mouths when the new budgets start kicking in. In the last century, it made the rounds with the wartime policies of the 40s, but this new rationing doesn’t have a western front to justify it — just yesterday’s glut.

abstract: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, the Guggenheim wants your video art and Alison Arngrim (Nellie Oleson on “Little House on the Prairie”) is off the prairie and on the Web.
snippet: On this week’s Tech Talk podcast, the Guggenheim wants your video art and Alison Arngrim (Nellie Oleson on “Little House on the Prairie”) is off the prairie and on the Web.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s New York Times Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein looks at a joint project of YouTube and the Guggenheim Museum to find and showcase the latest in video art. She talks to Nancy Spector, deputy director and chief curator of the Guggenheim Foundation, and Ed Sanders, senior marketing manager for YouTube, about how the project evolved and how it will work. Called “YouTube Play: A Biennial of Creative Video,” it’s open to anyone who submits a video by July 31. Up to 20 videos will be displayed at the Guggenheim Museum in New York on Oct. 21, with simultaneous showings at the museum’s other venues, in Bilbao, Berlin and Venice.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: YouTube and the Guggenheim

abstract: The House and Senate remain far apart on a variety of initiatives.

Then, in his State of the Union address in January, he emphasized the role small business would play in healing the nation’s wounded economy. But it is only now, eight months after that speech, that Congress finally seems ready to act. And the House and Senate are so far apart that it is not clear that they will be able to agree on a bill that contains more than just a few of the president’s ideas.

headline.main: Will Obama’s Small-Business Agenda Survive Congress?

abstract: Merck lost a second trial to reach a verdict over claims that its osteoporosis drug Fosamax caused so-called jaw death.
snippet: Merck lost a second trial to reach a verdict over claims that its osteoporosis drug Fosamax caused so-called jaw death.
lead_paragraph: Merck lost a second trial to reach a verdict over claims that its osteoporosis drug Fosamax caused so-called jaw death. The jury in New York set damages at $8 million in the case of Shirley Boles, 72, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., who said she developed osteonecrosis of the jaw by taking Fosamax. With osteonecrosis, a bone is no longer alive and cannot regenerate because of a lack of blood supply, according to the National Osteonecrosis Foundation’s Web site. The first Fosamax case resulted in a Merck victory in May. United States District Judge John F. Keenan, who is overseeing federal Fosamax litigation, scheduled three bellwether trials that might point the way to out-of-court settlements and show each side the other’s strategy. The third case is to be tried in November. “We believe the jury verdict was a result of plaintiff’s counsel’s inflammatory and prejudicial remarks,” Paul F. Strain, a lawyer for Merck, said in a statement.

headline.main: Jury Says Merck Must Pay $8 Million in Fosamax Case
headline.print_headline: Jury Says Merck Must Pay $8 Million In Fosamax Case

In a memo to the staff on Monday, Bill Keller, the paper’s executive editor, announced that Gerry Marzorati will be taking on a new role overseeing new initiatives at The Times. Mr. Marzorati will continue to edit the magazine through the summer as the paper searches for his successor. Mr. Keller said he would consider both internal and external candidates for the position. His note to the staff is below.

headline.main: Marzorati to Leave Magazine for New Post at The Times

abstract: A bunch of mathematical and placement problems involving the chessboard, with a passing mention of the World Chess Championship.
snippet: A bunch of mathematical and placement problems involving the chessboard, with a passing mention of the World Chess Championship.
lead_paragraph: Last week we discussed spooky action at a distance in Quantum Mechanics. This week we consider a game in which action at a distance is commonplace: chess. Actually, this puzzle is long overdue – it suffered a spooky displacement in time. I had meant to run it in late April or early May during the World Chess Championship in Sofia, Bulgaria, when challenger Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria took on reigning champion Vishwanathan (“Vishy”) Anand of India. Like boxing, the world chess championship is decided by a gladiatorial, head-to-head 12-round bout (over 18 days!) between the incumbent champion and a worthy challenger. Chess is a war-game after all!

headline.main: Numberplay: Maximum Protection on Board

abstract: A single mother finds ways to survive in the difficult government contract world and the male-dominated construction industry.
snippet: A single mother finds ways to survive in the difficult government contract world and the male-dominated construction industry.
lead_paragraph: Gail Warrior planned to use the Russian she studied in college to help her open an accounting firm in the former Soviet Union. Instead, she is chief executive and president of the Warrior Group, a company with $124 million in revenue and 58 employees that is based in DeSoto, Tex., and handles modular construction projects in 30 states. “Life happens,” said Ms. Warrior, 42. She recently discussed the deal that almost put her out of business, the nuances of winning government contracts and the balancing act of being a newly divorced parent to a 10-year-old son. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline.main: Learning to Be Tough Beneath a Hard Hat
